case_data.name: State of California v. Trump
case_data.plaintiff_description: The State of California and Gavin Newsom in his official capacity as Governor of California.
special_collections: Trump Administration 2.0: Challenges to the Government
case_data.summary:
This is one of several cases challenging President Trump’s implementation of tariffs.

Under the International Economic Emergency Powers Act (IEEPA), President Trump issued Executive Orders which instituted broad tariffs on imported goods and increased tariffs targeting specific countries such as China, Canada, and Mexico. This case challenged these tariffs.

On April 16, 2025, the State of California and Governor Gavin Newsom, represented by the State Attorney General, filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. They sued President Trump, the Department of Homeland Security, and DHS's component agency, U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The plaintiffs argued that President Trump’s executive orders imposing tariffs under IEEPA exceeded the authority granted by the statute. Given the serious consequences of imposing tariffs, the plaintiffs insisted that Congress should have explicitly authorized the president to take such unilateral actions; without such explicit authorization, the plaintiffs argued that the executive orders violated the Constitution's separation of powers principles.

The plaintiffs requested a declaration that the Executive Orders imposing the tariffs were unlawful, an injunction against the implementation or enforcement of the orders, and court costs. The case was assigned to District Judge Jacqueline Scott Corley. 

On April 17, 2025, the defendants filed a motion to transfer the case to the U.S. Court of International Trade (CIT), arguing that the court had exclusive jurisdiction over trade matters. On May 13, the plaintiffs submitted a motion for a preliminary injunction, claiming that California would face irreparable harm if the tariffs stayed in effect. A hearing on the defendants' motion to transfer the case took place on May 27.

On June 2, 2025, the court issued an order denying the defendants' motion to transfer the case and a judgment dismissing the case. The court found that the CIT had exclusive jurisdiction over a case if it "arises out of a United States law providing for tariffs." Here, the case arose out of a United States law (the Executive Order) creating tariffs, so the CIT has exclusive jurisdiction. However, the plaintiffs requested the court to dismiss, rather than transfer, the case, which the court did "to allow California to pursue a prompt appeal of the jurisdictional question" in the Ninth Circuit. 2025 WL 1569334. 

On June 2, the plaintiffs appealed to the Ninth Circuit and filed a motion to expedite the case on June 4. The Court of Appeals scheduled oral argument in the case for September 17. 

On September 10, defendants filed a Motion to Stay proceedings pending the Supreme Court of the United States’ resolution of two related cases: V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump and Learning Resources, Inc. v. Trump. On September 12, the court granted the stay.

The case is ongoing.
case_data.summary_short:
This case is one of several challenging President Trump’s 2025 tariffs.

Under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), President Trump issued orders putting tariffs on imported goods, including higher tariffs on China, Canada, and Mexico. On April 16, 2025, California and Governor Gavin Newsom, through the State Attorney General, sued President Trump, the Department of Homeland Security, and U.S. Customs and Border Protection in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. They argued the President did not have the power to impose these tariffs without clear approval from Congress. They also said the orders violated the Constitution’s separation of powers. California asked the court to declare the tariffs illegal, stop their enforcement, and award court costs.

Defendants asked the court to move the case to the U.S. Court of International Trade (CIT) on April 17, saying that court handles all tariff cases. California asked the court to block the tariffs on May 13. On June 2, the court denied the transfer and dismissed the case, saying the CIT has exclusive authority over tariff cases but allowing California to appeal quickly. California appealed to the Ninth Circuit that same day and requested faster review. Oral argument was scheduled for September 17.

On September 10, defendants asked the court to pause the case while the Supreme Court decides V.O.S. Selections, Inc. v. Trump and Learning Resources, Inc. v. Trump. The court granted the pause on September 12.

The case is still ongoing.

22  Pending before the Court is the Government’s motion to transfer this case to the U.S. Court 
23  of International Trade (“CIT”).  The question before the Court is not whether the challenged tariffs 
24  are constitutional; instead, the question is whether this action arises out of a law providing for 
25  tariffs such that the CIT has exclusive jurisdiction to decide whether the President was authorized 
26  to impose tariffs in the manner, and under the circumstances, in which he has.  See 28 U.S.C. § 
27  1581(i).  Having carefully considered the parties’ submissions, and with the benefit of oral 
28  argument on May 22, 2025, the Court concludes this action falls within the CIT’s exclusive 

Case 3:25-cv-03372-JSC     Document 62     Filed 06/02/25     Page 2 of 14
 
1  jurisdiction.  Because this lawsuit arises out of executive orders imposing tariffs, and because 
2  those executive orders are “provisions of law for all purposes,” 19 U.S.C. § 3004(c), this action 
3  arises out of laws providing for tariffs and this Court is divested of jurisdiction.  Because 
4  California requests dismissal rather than transfer to the CIT, transfer is not in the interest of 
5  justice.  So, the Court DENIES the motion to transfer and DISMISSES the case without prejudice.

19  This action arises out of President Trump’s executive orders imposing tariffs.  That is, the 
20  lawsuit challenging President Trump’s imposition of tariffs originates from, grows out of, and 
21  flows from the executive orders through which the President imposed tariffs.  See In re Border 
22  Infrastructure Env’t Litig., 915 F.3d 1213, 1220 (9th Cir. 2019) (noting “arising out of” is 
23  “ordinarily understood to mean ‘originating from,’ ‘having its origin in,’ ‘growing out of’ or 
24  ‘flowing from’ or in short, ‘incident to, or having connection with’”).  Those executive orders are 
25  laws of the United States.  They modify, or instruct the Department of Homeland Security to 
26  modify, the Harmonized Tariff Schedule, which is a statutory provision.  19 U.S.C. § 
27  3004(c)(1)(A).  Accordingly, the modifications themselves are statutory provisions.  Section 3004, 
28  setting forth the status of the Harmonized Tariff schedule, confirms this:

19  Because executive orders modifying the Harmonized Tariff Schedule are laws of the 
20  United States, and because the executive orders at issue here indisputably provide for tariffs, this 
21  civil action “arises out of [a] law of the United States providing for . . . tariffs.”  So, the CIT has 
22  exclusive jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1581(i)(1).  And because the action falls within the CIT’s 
23  exclusive jurisdiction, this Court lacks jurisdiction.  See K Mart Corp. v. Cartier, Inc., 485 U.S. 
24  176, 182–83 (1988) (“The District Court would be divested of jurisdiction . . . if this action fell 
25  within one of several specific grants of exclusive jurisdiction to the Court of International 
26  Trade.”); see also 28 U.S.C. § 1340 (“The district courts shall have original jurisdiction of any 
27  civil action arising under any Act of Congress providing for internal revenue, or revenue from 
28  imports or tonnage except matters within the jurisdiction of the Court of International Trade.”).

21  statutory period for seeking interlocutory review ha[d] elapsed.”  Kennecott Corp. v. U.S. Dist. Ct. 
22  for S. Dist. of California, 873 F.2d 1292, 1293 (9th Cir. 1989).  As these cases indicate, the 
23  “interest of justice” analysis emphasizes the plaintiff’s interests.  See also Amiti, 793 F.3d at 991 
24  (“[T]ransfer will often serve as a means to prevent the injustice of penalizing a party for an honest 
25  procedural mistake”); In re McCauley, 814 F.2d 1350, 1352 (9th Cir. 1987) (cleaned up) (stating 
26  section 1631 “serves to aid litigants who were confused about the proper forum for review”); 
27  Miller v. Hambrick, 905 F.2d 259, 262 (9th Cir. 1990) (concluding district court abused its 
28  discretion for failing to determine whether prisoner’s petition for writ of habitus corpus “could 
11 

Case 3:25-cv-03372-JSC     Document 62     Filed 06/02/25     Page 12 of 14
 
1  have been brought in the district of [his] ‘regular place of incarceration’ and whether transfer 
2  would have been in the interest of justice” under section 1631).  In this case, when California—the 
3  party who filed the lawsuit—requests dismissal rather than transfer, it is not in the interest of 
4  justice to transfer the case. 
5  At oral argument, the Government could not articulate why transfer over California’s 
6  objection serves the interests of justice.  The Government argued it is in the interest of justice to 
7  ensure the correct forum rules on California’s claims.  The Court agrees, and dismissal facilitates 
8  that result by allowing the Ninth Circuit to decide whether this Court has jurisdiction over a 
9  lawsuit challenging the President’s imposition of tariffs and/or to what extent district courts should 
10  consider the merits of a case in deciding if a matter falls within the CIT’s exclusive jurisdiction.   
11  The Government also argued Ninth Circuit precedent requires transfer rather than 
12  dismissal, noting in Pentax Corp. v. Myhra, 72 F.3d 708, 711 (9th Cir. 1995), the Ninth Circuit 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  “conclude[d] the prudent thing to do [was] to direct the district court to transfer the case to the CIT 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  so that the CIT [could] determine the question of its own jurisdiction.”  In Pentax, the plaintiff had 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  argued “the interests of justice require . . . transfer, because if the case is not transferred [the 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  plaintiff’s] claim may be barred by the statute of limitations.”  Id.  Without expressing an “opinion 
S d nr
ee 17  on the statute of limitations issue or whether the CIT would have had original jurisdiction,” the 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  Ninth Circuit transferred the case “so that the CIT [could] determine the question of its own 
19  jurisdiction.”  Id.  Like the section 1631 cases described above, the Pentax court’s decision to 
20  transfer was based on the plaintiff’s interest in resolving its claim.  The Court does not understand 
21  Pentax—or United States v. Universal Fruits & Vegetables Corp., 370 F.3d 829, 836–37 (9th Cir. 
22  2004), which cites Pentax—to mean section 1631 requires transfer over the plaintiff’s objection.  
23  Nor does the Court understand Pentax to mean the Court must transfer whenever there is 
24  ambiguity about the CIT’s jurisdiction.  Such interpretation would conflict with the language of 
25  section 1631, which requires transfer if it is in the interest of justice “[w]henever . . . a court . . . 
26  finds that there is a want of jurisdiction.”  28 U.S.C. § 1631.  So, section 1631 applies when a 
27  court has found jurisdiction lacking, not when a court thinks jurisdiction could be lacking.    
28  Following oral argument, the Government sought leave to file a supplemental brief 
12 

Case 3:25-cv-03372-JSC     Document 62     Filed 06/02/25     Page 13 of 14
 
1  responding to California’s request to dismiss rather than transfer the case.  (Dkt. No. 59.)  The 
2  Court granted the request.  (Dkt. No. 61.)  Having reviewed the Government’s supplemental brief, 
3  the Court is not persuaded transfer is in the interest of justice in this case.  The section 1631 cases 
4  the Government cites reinforce transfer as the proper remedy when it advances the plaintiff’s 
5  interests.  For example, in Taati v. Cigna Healthcare, Inc., No. CV 08-05164 MMM (PLAx), 2008 
6  WL 11423917, at *7 (C.D. Cal. Sept. 19, 2008), the court transferred the case to a forum where all 
7  the defendants were subject to personal jurisdiction to “protect [the plaintiff] from any prejudice 
8  resulting from her confusion.”  The court observed “[n]othing suggest[ed] that [the plaintiff] filed 
9  her action in California in bad faith; rather, given that she is pro se, and given the interpretation of 
10  the personal jurisdiction rules set out in her pleadings, it is clear that she was confused about the 
11  proper forum for review.  Id. (quotation marks omitted).  And in Amerijet International, Inc. v. 
12  United States Department of Homeland Security, 43 F. Supp. 3d 4, 21 (D.D.C. 2014), the court 
a 
tr in
uoro 13  concluded “transfer, not dismissal, [was] the preferable disposition” when it was the plaintiff who 
Cfi
 tla
cC 14  sought transfer and the defendants who “firmly reject[ed]” that proposition.  Here, the roles are 
i
rts fo
iD tc 15  reversed: California, the plaintiff—whose interest courts seek to protect in evaluating transfer 
 sir
et
tatsiD 16  under section 1631—requests dismissal whereas the Government requests transfer.   
S d nr
ee 17  The Government’s other case citations are unpersuasive because they involved different 
th
intr
Uo
N 18  provisions.  See Dearth v. Mukasey, 516 F.3d 413, 415-16 (6th Cir. 2008) (considering transfer for 
19  improper venue pursuant to sections 1404 and 1406); Concha v. London, 62 F.3d 1493, 1506 (9th 
20  Cir. 1995) (considering voluntary dismissal under Rule 41(a)(1)).  The Government also argues 
21  Congress “decided against making transfer orders immediately appealable” and dismissal here 
22  would “create a loophole to appellate jurisdiction.”  (Dkt. No. 59-1 at 2.)  But under section 1631, 
23  transfer is only required when it is “in the interest of justice.”  So, the statute apparently 
24  contemplates the present situation—in which the court concludes it lacks jurisdiction and that 
25  transfer is not in the interest of justice, leaving dismissal as the proper course of action. 
26  CONCLUSION 
27    Pursuant to section 1581(i), this action falls within the CIT’s exclusive jurisdiction and this 
28  Court is without jurisdiction.  Because California opposes transfer and instead requests dismissal, 
13 

Case 3:25-cv-03372-JSC     Document 62     Filed 06/02/25     Page 14 of 14
 
1  transfer is not in the interest of justice under section 1631.  So, the Court DENIES the 
2  Government’s motion to transfer and DISMISSES the case without prejudice.  A separate 
3  judgment order will issue.   
4    This Order disposes of Docket No. 9. 
5  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
6  Dated: June 2, 2025 
7

JACQUELINE SCOTT CORLEY

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 2 of 23
 
1  INTRODUCTION 
2  1.  President Donald J. Trump has launched an unprecedented tariff regime by relying on 
3  the International Economic Emergency Powers Act (IEEPA) and a purported national emergency 
4  arising from persistent trade deficits.   
5  2.  In just the last two weeks, President Trump has imposed a universal 10% tariff on 
6  virtually all imported goods and sweeping “reciprocal” tariffs on dozens of countries, before 
7  pausing the reciprocal tariffs for 90 days, and then increasing retaliatory tariffs on China to 145% 
8  in response to its countermeasures. 
9  3.  President Trump also invoked IEEPA and a purported national emergency arising 
10  from the trafficking of drugs and persons to impose, then pause, then re-impose, and then 
11  partially exempt, tariffs of up to 25% on Canada and Mexico, all in just over a month in February 
12  and March 2025. 
13  4.  Tariffs, however, are not among the numerous actions that IEEPA authorizes the 
14  President to take under a declared emergency; indeed, the word “tariff” does not appear in the 
15  relevant statute at all.  See 50 U.S.C. § 1702.  And no President has previously relied on IEEPA to 
16  impose tariffs in the half a century since its enactment. 
17  5.  The United States Constitution vests the authority to impose tariffs in Congress, see 
18  U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, and Congress has enacted numerous statutes delegating tariff authority to 
19  the President that expressly authorize imposition of tariffs, generally following required process 
20  and notice. 
21  6.  Rather than comply with the process and notice requirements set forth in those 
22  statutes, President Trump issued over a dozen executive orders invoking IEEPA, under the view 
23  that IEEPA grants him unilateral authority to impose unprecedented tariffs. 
24  7.  President Trump’s new tariff regime has already had devastating impacts on the 
25  economy, creating chaos in the stock and bond markets, wiping out hundreds of billions of dollars 
26  in market capitalization in hours, chilling investment in the face of such consequential 
27  Presidential action with no notice or process, and threatening to push the country into recession.  
28  These harms will only continue to grow, as President Trump’s tariffs are projected to shrink the 
 
  1   
 
Complaint (No. 25-cv-__________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 3 of 23
 
1  economy by $100 billion annually.1 
2  8.  As the fifth largest economy in the world, the State of California, along with its 
3  residents and small businesses, is directly harmed by the tariffs.  All will face higher costs due to 
4  the 10% universal tariffs now in effect on virtually all imported goods and the substantial 
5  additional tariffs imposed on Chinese, Mexican, and Canadian goods, with even higher costs 
6  threatened by the still-looming reciprocal tariffs.  And certain industries and businesses, including 
7  agriculture and entertainment, now face retaliatory tariffs imposed by China and threatened by 
8  other countries. 
9  9.  Under our constitutional system, the President may not rule by fiat.  Instead, “[t]he 
10  President’s power, if any, to issue [an] order must stem either from an act of Congress or from the 
11  Constitution itself.”  Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Sawyer, 343 U.S. 579, 585 (1952). 
12  10.  And where the economic and political significance is as staggering, and the power 
13  asserted is so novel and transformative as it is with the unprecedented tariffs that President Trump 
14  has imposed here, the President must have “clear congressional authorization” to justify his 
15  executive actions.  Biden v. Nebraska, 600 U.S. 477, 506 (2023). 
16  11.  IEEPA provides no such clear congressional authorization for President Trump’s 
17  tariffs, nor the vast expansion of Presidential power to tax all goods entering the United States on 
18  a whim. 
19  12.  Through this action, the State of California and California Governor Gavin Newsom 
20  seek declaratory and injunctive relief to block the tariffs imposed by President Trump pursuant to 
21  IEEPA because they are not authorized by that statute.    
22  JURISDICTION, VENUE, AND INTRADISTRICT ASSIGNMENT 
23  13.  This Court has jurisdiction under 28 U.S.C. § 1331 (action arising under the 
24  Constitution or laws of the United States).  An actual controversy exists between the parties 
25  within the meaning of 28 U.S.C. § 2201(a), and the Court may grant declaratory relief, injunctive 
26   
1 Where We Stand: The Fiscal, Economic, and Distributional Effects of All U.S. Tariffs Enacted 
27  in 2025 Through April 2, THE BUDGET LAB AT YALE UNIV. (Apr. 2, 2025), https://budgetlab.
yale.edu/research/where-we-stand-fiscal-economic-and-distributional-effects-all-us-tariffs-
28  enacted-2025-through-april. 
 
  2   
 
Complaint (No. 25-cv-__________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 4 of 23
 
1  relief, and other relief against Defendants pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–02 and the Court’s 
2  equitable powers. 
3  14.  Venue is proper in this District under 28 U.S.C. § 1391(e) because this is a judicial 
4  district in which the State of California resides. 
5  15.  Under Civil Local Rules 3-2(c) and 3-5(b), Plaintiffs allege that there is no basis for 
6  assignment of this action to any particular location or division of this Court. 
7  PARTIES 
8  16.  Plaintiff State of California, by and through Attorney General Rob Bonta, brings this 
9  action as a sovereign state in the United States of America.  The Attorney General is the chief law 
10  officer of the State and has the authority to file civil actions in order to protect public rights and 
11  interests.  Cal. Const. art. V, § 13; Cal. Gov’t Code § 12511.  This challenge is brought under the 
12  Attorney General’s independent constitutional, statutory, and common-law authority to bring suit 
13  and obtain relief on behalf of the State. 
14  17.  Plaintiff Gavin Newsom is the Governor of California.  Governor Newsom brings this 
15  challenge in his official capacity. 
16  18.  Defendant Donald J. Trump is the President of the United States.  He is sued in his 
17  official capacity.  
18  19.  Defendant Kristi Noem is the Secretary of Homeland Security.  She is sued in her 
19  official capacity. 
20  20.  Defendant Department of Homeland Security (DHS) is an independent federal 
21  agency.  
22  21.  Defendant Pete R. Flores is the Acting Commissioner for U.S. Customs and Border 
23  Protection (CBP).  He is sued in his official capacity. 
24  22.  Defendant U.S. Customs and Border Protection is an independent federal agency.   
25  23.  Defendants Noem, DHS, Flores, and CBP are collectively referred to as Agency 
26  Defendants. 
27 
28 
 
  3   
 
Complaint (No. 25-cv-__________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 5 of 23
 
1  FACTUAL BACKGROUND 
2  I.  No President Has Ever Imposed Tariffs Under IEEPA in Its Near-Half-Century 
History—Until President Trump Cited IEEPA to Unilaterally Issue Over a Dozen 
3  Executive Orders to Impose or Modify Tariffs in the Last Two-and-a-Half Months 
4  24.  No President other than President Trump has ever imposed tariffs under IEEPA in the 
5  nearly half century since its enactment in 1977. 
6  25.  President Trump has become the first and only such President, issuing over a dozen 
7  executive orders imposing or modifying tariffs pursuant to IEEPA since February 1, 2025 to 
8  date.2   
9  26.  A tariff is a tax placed on goods imported into a country.  It is assessed on the good at 
10  the port of entry, so the cost is borne by the distributor who is receiving the goods in the United 
11  States, not on the country of origin.  The tariffs’ effects are thus immediate. 
12  27.  DHS and CBP are the agencies collecting and enforcing President Trump’s tariffs. 
13  28.  These executive orders fall into two broad categories: (1) country-specific tariffs on 
14  Mexico, Canada, and China; and (2) universal tariffs and reciprocal tariffs. 
15  A.  President Trump’s Country-Specific Tariffs 
16  29.  On February 1, 2025, the President issued three executive orders imposing tariffs on 
17  imports from California’s three largest trading partners: Mexico, Canada, and China.  
18  30.  As described in detail below, Mexico and Canada are currently subject to tariffs of 
19  25% (with certain exceptions), and China is subject to tariffs of 145% in total. 
20  1.  Tariffs on Mexico  
21  31.  On February 1, 2025, President Trump issued an executive order imposing 25% 
22  tariffs on all products imported from Mexico, to go into effect just three days later, on February 4, 
23  2025.3 
24  32.  In the executive order imposing these tariffs, President Trump cited to IEEPA 
25 
 
26  2 Although President Trump threatened to impose tariffs under IEEPA in his first term, he 
suspended the implementation of those tariffs. 
27 
3 Exec. Order 14,194 (Feb. 1, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/
28  imposing-duties-to-address-the-situation-at-our-southern-border/. 
 
  4   
 
Complaint (No. 25-cv-__________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 6 of 23
 
1  (50 U.S.C. § 1701 et seq.), the National Emergencies Act (50 U.S.C. § 1601 et seq.) (NEA), 
2  section 604 of the Trade Act of 1974, as amended (19 U.S.C. § 2483), and section 301 of title 3, 
3  United States Code, but he specifically invoked authority for the order under section 
4  1702(a)(1)(B) of IEEPA.4 
5  33.  In the order, President Trump also cited a Proclamation issued on January 20, 2025, 
6  in which he declared a national emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border “with respect to the grave 
7  threat to the United States posed by the influx of illegal aliens and illicit drugs into the United 
8  States.”  The order “expand[ed]” the scope of that emergency to include “the failure of Mexico to 
9  arrest, seize, detain, or otherwise intercept [drug trafficking organizations], other drug and human 
10  traffickers, criminals at large, and illicit drugs.”   
11  34.  Just two days later, on February 3, 2025, President Trump issued another executive 
12  order announcing a pause on the 25% tariff on Mexican goods for one month.5   
13  35.  The tariffs went into effect on March 4, 2025. 
14  36.  Two days later, on March 6, 2025, President Trump issued another executive order 
15  exempting goods covered by the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) from the tariffs, 
16  effective March 7, 2025.6  USMCA-covered goods account for approximately half of imports 
17  from Mexico; the other half remain subject to the 25% tariffs, which are currently in effect.  
18 
19 
 
20  4 The NEA, section 604 of the Trade Act, and section 301 of title 3, do not give presidents any 
substantive authority to take any actions.  The NEA provides a framework for declaring a national 
21  emergency but does not itself provide for the President to exercise any authority to take action 
pursuant to that declaration.  See 50 U.S.C. § 1631 (“When the President declares a national 
22  emergency, no powers or authorities made available by statute for use in the event of an 
emergency shall be exercised unless and until the President specifies the provisions of law under 
23  which he proposes that he, or other officers will act.”).  Section 604 is a ministerial statute that 
provides that the President periodically update the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United 
24  States, a schedule that sets out the tariff rates for all merchandise imported into the United States.  
19 U.S.C. § 2483.  Section 301 is a general statute that simply provides that the President may 
25  delegate functions to subordinate officials.  3 U.S.C. § 301. 
26  5 Exec. Order 14,198 (Feb. 3, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/
progress-on-the-situation-at-our-southern-border/. 
27 
6 Exec. Order 14,232 (Mar. 6, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/
28  amendment-to-duties-to-address-the-flow-of-illicit-drugs-across-our-southern-border/.  
 
  5   
 
Complaint (No. 25-cv-__________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 7 of 23
 
1  2.  Tariffs on Canada 
2  37.  On February 1, 2025, President Trump issued an executive order imposing 25% 
3  tariffs on all imports from Canada, with the exception of energy resources, on which he imposed 
4  a 10% tariff.7  The tariffs were slated to go into effect just three days later, on February 4, 2025. 
5  38.  In the executive order imposing these tariffs, President Trump cited to IEEPA, the 
6  NEA, section 604 of the Trade Act of 1974, as amended, and 3 U.S.C. § 301, but he specifically 
7  invoked authority for the order under section 1702(a)(1)(B) of IEEPA. 
8  39.  Despite this order pertaining to Canada, President Trump cited the same Proclamation 
9  declaring a national emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border.  He “expand[ed]” this emergency to 
10  Canada, “to cover the threat to the safety and security of Americans, including the public health 
11  crisis of deaths due to the use of fentanyl and other illicit drugs, and the failure of Canada to do 
12  more to arrest, seize, detain, or otherwise intercept [drug trafficking organizations], other drug 
13  and human traffickers, criminals at large, and drugs.”  
14  40.  The same day the President issued his executive order, Canada announced it planned 
15  to impose 25% retaliatory tariffs on $155 billion worth of various goods imported from the 
16  United States.  In doing so, Canada noted that “[l]ess than 1 per cent of the fentanyl and illegal 
17  crossings into the United States come from Canada.”   
18  41.  Two days later, on February 3, 2025, President Trump issued another executive order 
19  announcing a pause on the tariffs on Canada for one month.   
20  42.  The tariffs went into effect on March 4, 2025. 
21  43.  Canada announced it was moving forward with 25% retaliatory tariffs on $30 billion 
22  of U.S. goods, which are currently in place.  Some of the goods affected by Canada’s retaliatory 
23  tariffs, such as wine, have a particularized impact on California, which produces approximately 
24  80% of American wine. 
25  44.  Two days later, President Trump exempted goods covered by the U.S.-Mexico-
26 
27   
7 Exec. Order 14,193 (Feb. 1, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/
28  imposing-duties-to-address-the-flow-of-illicit-drugs-across-our-national-border/. 
 
  6

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 8 of 23
 
1  Canada Agreement from the tariffs, effective March 7, 2025.8  USMCA-covered goods account 
2  for approximately 38% of goods from Canada; the majority of goods imported from Canada 
3  (62%) remain subject to the 25% tariffs. 
4  3.  Tariffs on China 
5  45.  On February 1, 2025, President Trump issued an executive order imposing a 10% 
6  tariff on China.9  This was imposed on top of pre-existing tariffs on certain Chinese goods (not 
7  imposed under IEEPA), for an effective tariff rate of 20%. 
8  46.  In the executive order imposing these tariffs, President Trump cited to IEEPA, the 
9  NEA, section 604 of the Trade Act of 1974, as amended, and 3 U.S.C. § 301, but he specifically 
10  invoked authority for the order under section 1702(a)(1)(B) of IEEPA. 
11  47.  Like the Mexico and Canada executive orders, President Trump’s order on China 
12  cited the same Proclamation declaring a national emergency at the U.S.-Mexico border.  He 
13  similarly now applied it to China: the order “expand[ed]” the scope of that emergency to include 
14  “the failure of the [People’s Republic of China] government to arrest, seize, detain, or otherwise 
15  intercept chemical precursor suppliers, money launderers, other [transnational criminal 
16  organizations], criminals at large, and drugs.”  
17  48.  On February 4, 2024, the additional 10% tariffs on China went into effect as 
18  scheduled, just three days after their initial announcement.  The same day, China announced 
19  retaliatory tariffs of 10–15% on a list of eighty U.S. products, effective February 10, 2025.  
20  49.  Unlike the Canada and Mexico tariffs, President Trump did not pause the tariffs on 
21  China.  Unsurprisingly, a tit-for-tat trade war with China ensued, with President Trump raising 
22  tariffs, and China responding in kind.10 
23   
8 Exec. Order 14,231 (Mar. 6, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/03/
24  amendment-to-duties-to-address-the-flow-of-illicit-drugs-across-our-northern-border-0c3c/. 
25  9 Exec. Order 14,195 (Feb. 1, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/02/
imposing-duties-to-address-the-synthetic-opioid-supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china/. 
26

27  effective immediately.  Exec. Order 14,228 (Mar. 3, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/
presidential-actions/2025/03/further-amendment-to-duties-addressing-the-synthetic-opioid-
28  supply-chain-in-the-peoples-republic-of-china/.  China responded the next day with new 10–15% 
  
  7   
 
Complaint (No. 25-cv-__________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 9 of 23
 
1  50.  As of April 16, 2025, Chinese goods are subject to a staggering 145% effective tariff 
2  rate in the United States, and U.S. goods are subject to 125% retaliatory tariffs in China.  China 
3  has also suspended all exports of rare-earth materials and magnets, which are crucial for the car, 
4  semiconductor, and aerospace industries, and is pausing its purchases of aircraft from Boeing, 
5  America’s largest exporter. 
6  B.  President Trump’s Universal and “Reciprocal” Tariffs 
7  51.  President Trump did not stop at imposing the aforementioned country-specific tariffs 
8  on the United States’ largest trading partners. 
9  52.  On April 2, 2025—a day he dubbed “Liberation Day”—President Trump broadened 
10  the scope of his IEEPA tariffs to the entire globe by announcing the most sweeping tariff increase 
11  since the Great Depression, again relying on a purported emergency in order to do so.11  
12  53.   As discussed infra, these tariffs include a 10% universal tariff on all U.S. trading 
13  partners and “reciprocal” tariffs of up to 50% on almost ninety specific countries. 
14  54.  In the executive orders imposing and modifying these tariffs,12 President Trump 
15 
 
16  tariffs on various U.S. agricultural products.  The United States then imposed reciprocal tariffs on 
multiple countries, discussed infra in Section I.B.2, adding new tariffs on China of 34%.  Exec. 
17  Order 14,257 (Apr. 2, 2025), https://www.whitehouse.gov/presidential-actions/2025/04/
regulating-imports-with-a-reciprocal-tariff-to-rectify-trade-practices-that-contribute-to-large-and-
18  persistent-annual-united-states-goods-trade-deficits/; see also id. annex I, https://www.
whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2025/04/Annex-I.pdf.  President Trump also issued an

6  142.  Defendants’ ultra vires conduct has caused and will continue to cause ongoing, 
7  irreparable harm to California, its Governor, and its residents. 
8  143.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2201, Plaintiffs are entitled to a declaration that the IEEPA 
9  Tariff Orders are unlawful, void, and of no effect.  
10  144.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–02, Plaintiffs are entitled to injunctive relief, 
11  enjoining all Defendants (other than the President) and their officers, employees, agents, servants, 
12  attorneys, and others acting in concert with them or subject to their control or direction, from 
13  implementing or enforcing the IEEPA Tariff Orders. 
14  COUNT II 
Separation of Powers – Usurping Legislative Authority 
15  (Against All Defendants) 
16  145.  Plaintiffs incorporate the preceding allegations as if alleged herein. 
17  146.  The separation-of-powers doctrine is “foundational” and “evident from the 
18  Constitution’s vesting of certain powers in certain bodies.”  Seila Law LLC v. CFPB, 591 U.S. 
19  197, 227 (2020). 
20  147.  The Constitution provides that “Congress shall have the Power To lay and collect 
21  Taxes, Duties, Imposts and Excises . . . .”  U.S. Const. art. I, § 8. 
22  148.  Congress’s power in this area is exhaustive.  Brushaber, 240 U.S. at 12 (“the 
23  authority conferred upon Congress by § 8 of article 1 ‘to lay and collect taxes, duties, imposts and 
24  excises’ is exhaustive and embraces every conceivable power of taxation”).   
25  149.  “The President’s power, if any, to issue [an] order must stem either from an act of 
26  Congress or from the Constitution itself.”  Youngstown, 343 U.S. at 585. 
27  150.  Where, as here, the President or the Executive Branch usurps and exercises a power 
28  that the Constitution has vested in Congress that Congress has not validly granted them, it 
 
  20   
 
Complaint (No. 25-cv-__________) 
 

Case 3:25-cv-03372     Document 1     Filed 04/16/25     Page 22 of 23
 
1  violates the separation-of-powers doctrine. 
2  151.  Accordingly, President Trump’s conduct in issuing the IEEPA Tariff Orders violates 
3  the separation-of-powers doctrine. 
4  152.  Agency Defendants’ conduct in implementing the tariffs that President Trump has 
5  imposed violates the separation-of-powers doctrine. 
6  153.  Defendants’ unconstitutional conduct has caused and will continue to cause ongoing, 
7  irreparable harm to California, its Governor, and its residents. 
8  154.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2201, Plaintiffs are entitled to a declaration that the IEEPA 
9  Tariff Orders are unlawful, void, and of no effect.  
10  155.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–02, Plaintiffs are entitled to injunctive relief, 
11  enjoining all Defendants (other than the President) and their officers, employees, agents, servants, 
12  attorneys, and others acting in concert with them or subject to their control or direction, from 
13  implementing or enforcing the IEEPA Tariff Orders. 
14  PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
15  WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs State of California, by and through Attorney General Rob Bonta, 
16  and Gavin Newsom, in his official capacity as Governor of California, respectfully request that 
17  this Court: 
18  1.  Declare that President Trump’s IEEPA Tariff Orders are unlawful and void, because 
19  they were issued ultra vires in excess of statutory authority and/or because they are 
20  unconstitutional and violate separation of powers, pursuant to the Declaratory Judgment Act, 
21  28 U.S.C. §§ 2201–02; 
22  2.  Enjoin Agency Defendants (and all of their officers, employees, agents, servants, 
23  attorneys, and others acting in concert with them or subject to their control or direction) from 
24  taking any action to implement or enforce President Trump’s IEEPA Tariff Orders; 
25  3.  Award Plaintiffs costs, expenses, and reasonable attorney’s fees, pursuant to the 
26  Equal Access to Justice Act, 28 U.S.C. § 2412; and 
27  4.  Grant such other relief as the Court deems just and proper.
